My son<S>1121</S>, attend<S>7181</S> unto my wisdom<S>2451</S>, and bow<S>5186</S> thine ear<S>241</S> to my understanding<S>8394</S>:
That thou mayest regard<S>8104</S> discretion<S>4209</S>, and that thy lips<S>8193</S> may keep<S>5341</S> knowledge<S>1847</S>.
For the lips<S>8193</S> of a strange woman<S>2114</S> drop<S>5197</S> as an honeycomb<S>5317</S>, and her mouth<S>2441</S> is smoother<S>2509</S> than oil<S>8081</S>: <sup>mouth: Heb. palate</sup>
But her end<S>319</S> is bitter<S>4751</S> as wormwood<S>3939</S>, sharp<S>2299</S> as a twoedged<S>6310</S> sword<S>2719</S>.
Her feet<S>7272</S> go down<S>3381</S> to death<S>4194</S>; her steps<S>6806</S> take hold<S>8551</S> on hell<S>7585</S>.
Lest thou shouldest ponder<S>6424</S> the path<S>734</S> of life<S>2416</S>, her ways<S>4570</S> are moveable<S>5128</S>, that thou canst not know<S>3045</S> them.
Hear<S>8085</S> me now therefore, O ye children<S>1121</S>, and depart<S>5493</S> not from the words<S>561</S> of my mouth<S>6310</S>.
Remove<S>7368</S> thy way<S>1870</S> far<S>7368</S> from her, and come not nigh<S>7126</S> the door<S>6607</S> of her house<S>1004</S>:
Lest thou give<S>5414</S> thine honour<S>1935</S> unto others<S>312</S>, and thy years<S>8141</S> unto the cruel<S>394</S>:
Lest strangers<S>2114</S> be filled<S>7646</S> with thy wealth<S>3581</S>; and thy labours<S>6089</S> be in the house<S>1004</S> of a stranger<S>5237</S>; <sup>thy wealth: Heb. thy strength</sup>
And thou mourn<S>5098</S> at the last<S>319</S>, when thy flesh<S>1320</S> and thy body<S>7607</S> are consumed<S>3615</S>,
And say<S>559</S>, How have I hated<S>8130</S> instruction<S>4148</S>, and my heart<S>3820</S> despised<S>5006</S> reproof<S>8433</S>;
And have not obeyed<S>8085</S> the voice<S>6963</S> of my teachers<S>3384</S>, nor inclined<S>5186</S> mine ear<S>241</S> to them that instructed<S>3925</S> me!
I was almost<S>4592</S> in all evil<S>7451</S> in the midst<S>8432</S> of the congregation<S>6951</S> and assembly<S>5712</S>.
Drink<S>8354</S> waters<S>4325</S> out of thine own cistern<S>953</S>, and running waters<S>5140</S> out of<S>8432</S> thine own well<S>875</S>.
Let thy fountains<S>4599</S> be dispersed<S>6327</S> abroad<S>2351</S>, and rivers<S>6388</S> of waters<S>4325</S> in the streets<S>7339</S>.
Let them be only thine own, and not strangers'<S>2114</S> with thee.
Let thy fountain<S>4726</S> be blessed<S>1288</S>: and rejoice<S>8055</S> with the wife<S>802</S> of thy youth<S>5271</S>.
Let her be as the loving<S>158</S> hind<S>365</S> and pleasant<S>2580</S> roe<S>3280</S>; let her breasts<S>1717</S> satisfy<S>7301</S> thee at all times<S>6256</S>; and be thou ravished<S>7686</S> always<S>8548</S> with her love<S>160</S>. <sup>satisfy: Heb. water thee</sup> <sup>be thou: Heb. err thou always in her love</sup>
And why wilt thou, my son<S>1121</S>, be ravished<S>7686</S> with a strange woman<S>2114</S>, and embrace<S>2263</S> the bosom<S>2436</S> of a stranger<S>5237</S>?
For the ways<S>1870</S> of man<S>376</S> are before<S>5227</S> the eyes<S>5869</S> of the LORD<S>3068</S>, and he pondereth<S>6424</S> all his goings<S>4570</S>.
His own iniquities<S>5771</S> shall take<S>3920</S> the wicked<S>7563</S> himself, and he shall be holden<S>8551</S> with the cords<S>2256</S> of his sins<S>2403</S>. <sup>sins: Heb. sin</sup>
He shall die<S>4191</S> without instruction<S>4148</S>; and in the greatness<S>7230</S> of his folly<S>200</S> he shall go astray<S>7686</S>.
